model_completion: Mukesh Ambani is an Indian businessman and the chairman and managing director of Reliance Industries Limited (RIL). He is the richest person in India, with a net worth of $27.4 billion as of March 2016. Mukesh Ambani was born on April 19, 1957 in Aden, Yemen to a wealthy family. He attended Stanford University and graduated from Harvard Business School. In 1981, he joined Reliance, which was founded by his father Dhirubhai Ambani. RIL is now one of the largest companies in India, with interests in energy, petrochemicals, textiles, natural resources, retail, and telecommunications.

Massimo Vignelli was an Italian-American designer and architect. He studied at the Politecnico di Milano, and later moved to the United States. Vignelli is known for his work on the New York City Subway map in 1972, as well as many other designs. Massimo Vignelli passed away in 2014.

Born in Zanzibar, Tanzania on September 5, 1946, Freddie Mercury was the lead singer of the rock band Queen. He died of AIDS in 1991. Queen's hits include "Bohemian Rhapsody," "We Will Rock You," and "Another One Bites the Dust."

Socrates was an ancient Greek philosopher, who lived in Athens from 469 to 399 BC. He is widely considered the father of Western philosophy. Socrates questioned and discussed different ideas and concepts through his philosophical method called the Socratic method. His most famous pupil was Plato. Socrates died at the age of 70 after being sentenced to death by drinking poison hemlock.

Born in Romania, Elie Wiesel was a Jewish-American writer and Nobel Peace Prize laureate. Wiesel is known for his memoir Night, which describes his experiences during the Holocaust. He died on July 2, 2016 at the age of 87.

Robin Williams was an American actor and comedian. He appeared in many popular films, such as "Good Morning, Vietnam," "Dead Poets Society," "Mrs. Doubtfire," and "Good Will Hunting." Robin Williams won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his role in "Good Will Hunting" in 1998. He died on August 11, 2014 at the age of 63.

1933 - Born in Calcutta, India. 1958 - Received his PhD from Oxford University. 1972-1978 - Professor at Harvard University. 1998 - Nobel Prize in Economics. 2014 - Elected to the United States Senate.

Born in Toronto, Canada, Isadore Sharp founded the Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts in 1960. Today, the company has over 85 hotels and resorts worldwide. Isadore Sharp is also the founder of the International Hotel Investment Forum (IHIF), which takes place annually in Berlin, Germany.

Elizabeth Blackwell was the first woman to graduate from medical school in the United States, in 1849. She graduated from Geneva Medical College in New York, and went on to open her own medical practice. In 1857, she founded the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, which is now called the Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania. Elizabeth Blackwell died in 1910.

Nobu Matsuhisa is a Japanese chef and restaurateur, known for his sushi and Japanese cuisine. Born in Japan, Nobu Matsuhisa moved to the United States at the age of 18. He opened his first restaurant, Matsuhisa, in Beverly Hills, California in 1987. Since then, Nobu has expanded to over 30 locations around the world, including New York City, London, Tokyo, and Las Vegas. Nobu Matsuhisa was awarded the James Beard Foundation Award for Outstanding Restaurant Design in 2006.

Born in 1973, Larry Page is an American computer scientist and co-founder of Google, along with Sergey Brin. Page and Brin met at Stanford University, where they developed the Google search engine. In 2015, Page became CEO of Alphabet Inc., which owns Google. Page has been awarded the Marconi Prize (2004), the Lemelson-MIT Prize (2006), and the Presidential Medal of Freedom (2015).

Winona LaDuke is an American activist and author. She was born in 1959 on the White Earth Indian Reservation in Minnesota, and she has been active in Native American causes for many years. LaDuke founded the group Honor the Earth in 1993 to raise awareness about environmental issues facing indigenous communities. In 2008, LaDuke ran as the Green Party vice presidential candidate with Ralph Nader.

Greta Gerwig is an American actress and filmmaker. She was born in Sacramento, California in 1983. Gerwig has appeared in films such as Frances Ha, Mistress America, and Lady Bird. Gerwig directed the critically acclaimed film Lady Bird, which won Best Picture at the 2018 Golden Globe Awards.

José Mujica was the President of Uruguay from 2010 to 2015. He was born in 1935 and spent most of his life as a peasant farmer. In 1963, he joined the Tupamaros guerrilla movement, which fought against the military dictatorship in Uruguay. After spending 14 years in prison, Mujica became a senator in 2005. He was elected president in 2010, and during his presidency, he legalized abortion and same-sex marriage.

Hideki Matsuyama is a Japanese professional golfer. He was born in 1992 and turned pro in 2010. Matsuyama has won several tournaments on the PGA Tour, including the WGC-Bridgestone Invitational in 2017. Matsuyama is currently ranked as one of the top golfers in the world.

Born in 1989 in San Dimas, California, Alex Morgan is an American soccer player and Olympic gold medalist. She plays for the Orlando Pride in the National Women's Soccer League, and was part of the U.S. women's national soccer team that won the gold medal at the 2012 Summer Olympics in London. In 2015, she scored a goal in the final match against Japan to win the World Cup.

Born into slavery in 1797, Sojourner Truth was an abolitionist and women's rights activist. She escaped from slavery in 1826 with her infant daughter, and became a prominent speaker for the abolitionist movement. In 1851, she delivered her famous "Ain't I a Woman?" speech at the Ohio Women's Rights Convention. Sojourner Truth died in 1883.

Born in South Africa, Elon Musk moved to Canada as a child. He studied at the University of Pennsylvania and dropped out at age 24 to start his company, PayPal. In 2003, he founded SpaceX, which has developed rockets and spacecraft for NASA. In 2008, he co-founded Tesla Motors, an electric car manufacturer, and in 2015, he founded SolarCity, a solar energy company. Elon Musk is also the founder of OpenAI, a nonprofit research company that develops artificial intelligence.

Cindy Sherman is an American photographer and artist, known for her conceptual portraits. Born in 1954, Cindy Sherman grew up in Long Island, New York. She received a BFA from the State University of New York at Buffalo in 1976, and an MFA from the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, California in 1980. Sherman's work has been exhibited in many museums around the world, including the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Tate Modern in London, and the Centre Georges Pompidou in Paris.

Born in 1957 in New York City, Katie Couric is an American journalist and television host. She was the first female anchor of 'CBS Evening News' (1991-2006), and has hosted several talk shows, including 'Katie' (2012-present). Couric has won numerous awards for her journalism work, including two Emmy Awards and a Peabody Award.

Bad Bunny is a Puerto Rican reggaeton singer and rapper. He was born in San Juan, Puerto Rico in 1994. His debut album, 'X 100PRE,' was released in 2018. Bad Bunny has collaborated with artists such as Daddy Yankee and Cardi B.

Esther Duflo is an American economist and the winner of the 2019 Nobel Prize in Economics, along with Abhijit Banerjee and Michael Kremer. Born in Paris, France, Duflo earned her PhD from MIT in 2009. She is currently a professor at MIT and the founder and director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL). Duflo has done extensive research on poverty alleviation and development economics.

Richard Pryor was an American comedian and actor. He was known for his uncompromising examination of racism and topical contemporary issues in his stand-up comedy, which often included vulgar language and racial epithets. Pryor won four Grammy Awards and received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 1976. His body of work includes films such as 'Silver Streak' (1976), 'Which Way Is Up?' (1977), 'The Mack' (1973), and 'Brewster's Millions' (1985). Richard Pryor died in 2005 at the age of 65.

Tex Avery was an American animator and cartoonist, known for his wacky characters and comical violence. He created the popular cartoon character Bugs Bunny, and worked at Warner Brothers from 1935 to 1955. Avery's most famous cartoons include 'Red Hot Riding Hood,' 'The Wolf Who Came to Dinner,' and 'One Froggy Evening.' Tex Avery died in 1980.

Dave Chappelle is an American comedian and actor, best known for his sketch comedy show 'Chappelle's Show.' He was born in Ohio in 1973, and began doing stand-up comedy when he was 14 years old. His first big break came in 1993, when he was cast as the star of the hit TV series 'Chappelle's Show,' which ran from 2003 to 2006. Dave Chappelle has also appeared in several movies, including 'Half Baked,' 'The Nutty Professor,' and 'Blue Streak.'

Zaha Hadid was an Iraqi-British architect who designed many innovative buildings around the world. She won the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004, and became the first woman to win the prize. Hadid's most famous works include the Guangzhou Opera House in China, the London Aquatics Centre for the 2012 Summer Olympics, and the Heydar Aliyev Center in Baku, Azerbaijan. Zaha Hadid died in March 2016 at the age of 65.

Mary Wollstonecraft was an English writer, philosopher, and advocate for women's rights. She wrote the book "A Vindication of the Rights of Woman," which argued that women should be treated as equals to men. Wollstonecraft died in 1797 at age 38 from complications during childbirth.

Warren Buffett is an American investor, businessman, and philanthropist. He is the CEO and largest shareholder of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., and one of the world's wealthiest people. Buffett was born in Omaha, Nebraska in 1930, and began investing at the age of 11. He attended the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, and started his own company Buffett Partnership in 1956. Buffett is known for his investment philosophy, "value investing", which he detailed in his 1991 book The Intelligent Investor. Buffett has donated most of his wealth to charity through the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation.

George Denis Patrick Carlin was an American stand-up comedian, actor, and author. Born in New York City, Carlin began his career in the 1950s. He later became known for his "Seven Dirty Words" routine, which was controversial at the time but eventually led to a U.S. Supreme Court case. Carlin's best-known works include 'The Seven Words You Can Never Say on Television,' 'Brain Droppings,' and 'George Carlin: 40 Years of Comedy.' George Carlin died in 2008 at the age of 71.

Quentin Tarantino is an American film director, screenwriter, and actor. He is known for his films Pulp Fiction, Reservoir Dogs, Kill Bill, and Django Unchained. Tarantino's films are often violent and have strong language. His films have won many awards, including the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay for Pulp Fiction in 1994 and the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival for Inglourious Basterds in 2009.

Born in 1997, Simone Biles is an American gymnast who won four gold medals at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. Biles is the first female gymnast to win three consecutive world all-around titles, and she has the most World Championship gold medals of any gymnast. In 2016, Biles became the first woman to win back-to-back Olympic gold medals in the individual all-around competition.

Novak Djokovic is a professional tennis player from Serbia. He was born on May 22, 1987 in Belgrade, Serbia. As a junior, Novak Djokovic won the Australian Open and Wimbledon in 2003. In 2007, he became the youngest man to be ranked No. 1 in the world. Novak Djokovic has won 12 Grand Slam singles titles, including six Australian Opens, three French Opens, and three US Opens. He is currently ranked No. 1 in the world.

20th century Russian-American writer and philosopher, Ayn Rand was born in St. Petersburg, Russia in 1905. She moved to the United States in 1926 and became a naturalized citizen in 1931. Rand's best known work is her novel 'The Fountainhead,' published in 1943. Rand also wrote the novels 'Atlas Shrugged' (1957) and 'Anthem' (1938). Ayn Rand died in 1982.

Rumi was a Persian poet, theologian, and Sufi mystic. Born in 1207 in what is now Afghanistan, Rumi wrote more than 3,000 poems about love, spirituality, and the relationship between mankind and God. His most famous work is the "Mathnawi," an epic poem that has been translated into many languages. Rumi died in 1273.

Born in Romania, Constantin Brancusi was a famous sculptor who created many iconic works of art. His most famous work is 'The Kiss', which is located at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. Brancusi died in 1957.

Born in Scotland in 1736, James Watt was an inventor and engineer who improved the steam engine. Watt's steam engine was crucial to the Industrial Revolution, as it made possible the development of factories that produced goods on a large scale. Watt died in 1819 at the age of 83.

Christiaan Barnard was a South African heart surgeon, who performed the first human-to-human heart transplant in 1967. He performed more than 150 heart transplants during his career. In 2008, Barnard died at the age of 78.

Born in Argentina in 1936, Jorge Mario Bergoglio chose the name Pope Francis when he became the 266th and current Pope of the Catholic Church on March 13, 2013. He is the first Jesuit pope, the first from the Americas, and the first pope from the Southern Hemisphere. Pope Francis has been praised for his humility, emphasis on God's mercy, concern for the poor and commitment to interfaith dialogue.

Tina Fey is an American actress, comedian, writer, and producer. She was born in Upper Darby, Pennsylvania in 1970. Fey began her career as a featured player in the Chicago improv group Second City. In 1999, she created and starred in the popular NBC series '30 Rock,' for which she has won four Emmy Awards. Fey is also known for her work on 'Saturday Night Live' and 'Mean Girls.'

Samuel Finley Breese Morse was an American painter and inventor. He is best known for developing the Morse code, a code used to transmit messages over long distances using electricity. Morse also developed the telegraph, which was a device that sent messages over wires. The first telegraph message was sent on May 24, 1844, from Washington D.C. to Baltimore, Maryland. Morse's invention helped to develop communication and transportation around the world.
